title: Nordertor
text:
The Nordertor () is an old <a href="City%20gate">town gate</a> in <a href="Flensburg">Flensburg</a>, <a href="Germany">Germany</a>, which was built around 1595. Today the <a href="landmark">landmark</a> is used as a symbol for Flensburg.
History.
The <a href="Wall">town wall</a> of Flensburg was built step by step from 1345 onwards. A town gate, named "Norder Porte", was built in the northern section of the wall. At the end of the 16th century it was replaced by the Nordertor, a building with <a href="Crow-stepped%20gable">stepped gables</a> and <a href="arch">arch</a>way. At this time the Nordertor marked the northern <a href="Border">boundary</a> of the town. It was a checkpoint that was closed at night.
On the north face of the gate are two <a href="Commemorative%20plaque">plaques</a>. The left one bears the royal coat of arms of King <a href="Christian%20IV%20of%20Denmark">Christian IV</a>, 1577-1648 and the <a href="Latin">Latin</a> words: "Regna Firmat Pietas" — Piety strengthens the Realm. The right one bears the coat of arms of Flensburg with the <a href="German%20language">German</a> words: "Friede ernährt, Unfrieden verzehrt" — <a href="Peace">Peace</a> nurtures, <a href="War">strife</a> devours. Also to be seen is the date of renovation, inscribed as "Renov. 1767". The town gate was <a href="building%20restoration">restored</a> in the time of <a href="Christian%20VII%20of%20Denmark">Christian VII</a>, 1749-1808. The left plaque is most likely the older of the two, possibly from the time when the Nordertor was built.
In 1796 a ban on building outside the town walls ended, and the town began to expand beyond. The suburb of Neustadt (Danish: "Nystaden", meaning "Newtown") was built in the neighborhood of the Nordertor. In 1913/14 the gate was restored by the <a href="architect">architect</a> <a href="Paul%20Ziegler">Paul Ziegler</a>, and a clock was installed. In 1966 the <a href="Deutsche%20Bundespost">Deutsche Bundespost</a> issued a 30 <a href="Deutsche%20Mark">Pfennig</a> <a href="Postage%20stamp">stamp</a> with the gate's image. Over 3 billion of these stamps for letter post were sold. In the 1990s the gate was again restored and the clock was removed. In 2004 the gate was licensed as a venue for <a href="Wedding">civil wedding</a>s, so that weddings are now performed in a room above the archway of the gate.
